document.text: sister Southern States, which had already seceded. The call went out for volunteers to defend the firesides of the Old Do minion. Appomattox County responded nobly. A Cavalry Company was formed under the command of Capt. Joel W. Flood, becoming Co. H of the 2nd Va. Cavalry. A Company of Heavy Artillery was formed under Capt. James Robertson. A Company of Infantry under Capt. Thos. P. Mat thews, and another Company was formed under Capt. Wm. H. Abbitt, and quite a number of Appomattox citizens living near the rim of the county joined companies from adjoining coun ties. With hearts aflame and bodies dedicated to the Cause they held dear, they went to the front and shared the destiny of the heroes in Gray. Weakened by casualties, new calls came for volunteers, and long after the war, there was a scarcity of able bodied men in the County. Then came April 9, 1865, and the hand of destiny wrote finis across the scroll of four mighty years of struggle Destiny selected Appomattox for one of the major events oi history. Today there is hardly a town- or village in America, that has not heard of Appomattox. Thus ended in this Coun ty, one of the greatest Civil Wars ever chronicled in the files of Time, and at Appomattox began a new page in the history of America. Military rule was established shortly after April 9, 1865. Al county officers were replaced by military appointees. These were men who were selected upon the recommendation of the incumbents, and were willing to take the Iron Clad Oath. In the fall of 1866, an election was held under the Under wood Constitution, which put into effect the 13th and 14th Amendments to the Constitution of the United States, and a new slate of officers were named. Geo. T. Peers became Clerk Wm. T. Johnson Sheriff W. J. Collins, Commissioner of the Revenue the Office of County Treasurer was created Supervisors were provided for, and the ounty Government, practically as we have it now was estab lished. The ravages of four years of war were apparent, and Ap pomattox along with her sister counties, began to repair the wounds. The following years called forth the character and ability of her people, and the present institutions of our Coun- -y are but a tribute to their untiring labor and foresight. From 1870 to the present has been a period of rebuilding and achievement. From its creation the County has been served until now by the following Officers CIRCUIT JUDGESJudges G. A. Wingfield, J. D. document.text: Mr. James Hudson Cheatham, 86, long-time proprietor of the Hotl Appomattox, died here on Suiday, Septamber 2, after an illness of sev eral weeks. as Born in Appomattox County Jane 7, 1865, he was the son of Thomas I. and Virginia Cawthorne Cheat ham. He and his widow, Mrs. Mollie Cheatham, had been proprietors of the local hotel for some 33 years. He was a member of the Evergreen Baptist Church. Surviving, in addition to his wid ow are a pister, Mrs. Bmmaline Banton, of Lynchburg two daugh ters, Mrs. L. M. Ringham, of Blue- field, and Mrs. Havilah Babcock, of Columbia, S. C. two sons, Tucker T. and Z. E. Cheatham, of Appo mattox and Evergreen four broth ers, Floyd Cheatham, of Birming ham Samuel D. Cheatham, of Pen sacola, Florida Jay Hubbard and Thomas Cheatham, both of Miami, Florida. Funeral services were held Mon day at 400 P. M. at the Ever green Cemetery, conducted by the Rev. Tearle Brown, pastor. Active pallbearers were Harry Johnson, Julian White, Daniel Jennings, A. A. Babcock, E. T. Mitchell and Wil bur McDearmon.

document.text: Mr. Sears, or Tad as he was better known here, was born June 24, 1891, at Hixburg, this county, the son of the late Samuel and Colie Gilliam Sears. He attended the lo cal high school and then went to Fork Union Military Academy. Up on graduation there, he came to Appomattox and began his success ful career as a clerk in the Hard ware store. His abilities earned him promotion and he became vice-pres ident and manager, and thei upon the death of the late W. M. Han cock, he was made president of the firm. He served three years as a mem ber of the town council of Appo mattox and was actively identified with business and social life of the town and county. Ue was a mem ber of Liberty Baptist church. He is survived by his widow, Mr. Winifred Scott Sears one son, Dan iel Scott Sears, 18, a student of Hampton-Sydney college and two brothers, E . Percy Sears, of Hix burg Herman D. Sears, of High Point, N .C ., and by three sisters, Mrs. Pearl Marshall, of Hixburg Mrs. A . R. Harwood and Mrs. W . IS. Taylor, of Appomifttox. Funeral services will be held to morrow, Friday, at 3 P . M. from the Liberty Baptist church, conducted by the Rev. W . M.Thompson. Active pallbearers will be Joel W . Flood, J. A . Burke, W. E . Hancock, Dr. C. H. Swing, W.M. Morris and Dr. L. L. Gayle.Hon orary pallbearers will be J . O. Cole, C. C. Poe, O. W . Martin, T. M. Martin, Dr. D. N. Twy- man, T . J . Ligon, C. document.text: The entire community was sad dened by the passing of Edmund Hudson Cawthorne, at his home in the Ould Apartments Friday morn ing. Prior to his death he had been a patient in the Virginia Baptist Hospital for a number of weeks. H-owever, he had recovered suffi- fieienily to come home and walk about the place.. Mr. Cawthorne was born sixty- nine years ago in Appomattox Co unty, the son of the late John Da vid and Mary Phelps Cawthorne.He was for a number of years a val ued employee of the Virginian rail road. In his later, years he was connected with various mercantile establishments. Mr. Cawthorne liv ed at one time in Roanoke and Brookneal for thirteen years and of her places where he left many friends who mourn his passing. He was a member of Liberty Baptist Church at Appjomattox, Lakeland Lodge, A. F.  A. M., Roanoke. He is survived by his widow, the former Nultie McDearmon two sons, John Raymond, of Roanoke, and Howard DuVal, of Altavista, two grandchildren, Barbara Anne and William DuVal Cawthorne. Al so the following brothers and sis ters J. Russell Cawthorne, of Spout Spring H. P. Cawthorne, of Roanoke, Mrs. Samuel Jennings, of Evergreen, and Mrs. Walter Far rar, of Petersburg.  Funeral services were conducted Sunday af ernoon at Liberty Bap tist Church. The Rev. H. Frederick Jones, pastor of the church, was as sisted by the Rev. R. E. Redding, the Rev. W. R. Reed, a id the Rev. A C Lawson.  Blessed Assurance and My Hope is Buii on Nothing Less, favorite hymr.s of Mr.Caw-  homes, were sung by the church choir. Interment took place in the Evergreen cemetery. Active pallbearers were H. W. McKinney, C. Lewis McDearmon,J. D. Jennings, J. K. Hamilton, El more C.. Farrar and Fred C. Caw thorne. A large gro-upi of local citi zens acted as honorary pallbearers. Mr. Cawthorne was one of the most popular and loved citizens of Appomattox. He possessed, in a marked degree, the spirit of friend liness and radiant good cheer. His smiles were scattered alike on rich and pool1, young and old, high and low. His greeting was reminescent of the Jine courtesy that has ever characterized the Virginia gentle man. Though he had been in frail health, a number of years, he pre ferred to work whenever it was humanly possible. He wished t o cotnribute his bit to life. His suf ferings he bore with rare courage. He was a devoted husband and father, and a faithful friend. W e like to think of him as Stepping on shore, and finding it Heaven Of taking hold of a hand, and find ing it Gods hand Of hreathin new air and finding it celestial air Of feeling invigorated, and finding it immortality Of passing from storm and tempest, Jo an unknown ealm  Of waking, and finding it Heaven.

document.text: Mrs. Mollie H. Lawson is ill at her home here. We are sorry to hear that Mr. Walter D. Hunter, of Route One is quite sick with flu. Mr. and Mrs. Sam Evans of Peters burg, will spend Wednesday with Mrs. Evans mother, Mrs. Jennie Johnson. Miss Betty Jane Wingfield, of Radford College, Radford, spent the weekend at her home here. Flatwood Blackwell, of VPI, spent the weekend with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Curtis Blackwell, here. Mr. and Mrs. K. E. Coleman and son, Ken, were weekend guests of Mr. and Mrs. H. G. Johnson. Mr. and Mrs. Babby Lawson, of Richmond, spent the weekend here with relatives. Mrs. Samuel S. Shouse returned last week from a trip to New York City. Mrs. Mary Tucker, of Drakes Branch, was a visitor in the home of C. S. McDearmon last week. Mrs. C. E. Coleman, of Roanoke, spent the weekend with her sister, Mrs. W. L. Brown. Mr. Harold Coleman, of Roanoke, visited his aunt, Mrs, W. L. Brown, recently. Dinner guest of ifvv-ini Mrs. Paul Cawthorn Saturday evening were Mr. and Mrs. T. J. Cawthorn and son, Jack, and Mrs. Eva Cawthorn. Mrs. W. D. Mason, of Rice, visited her sister, Mrs. Matilda Hancock, and her brother, W. J. LeGrand, last week. W. R. Holt, who has been seriously ill and under observation in the Farmville Hospital, is now respond ing satisfactorily to treatment. Mrs. Sam Anderson came home iSunday after spending several days with her sister, Mrs. W. B. Thomas of Evergreen, who has been quite ill. She is much better at this writing. Mr. and Mrs. E. Carroll Smith and children spent Sunday with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Smith in Charlottesville. Mrs. Sam Witt Jr., is a patient at the St. Elizabeths Hospital in Rich mond. Mrs. Witt is the daughter of C. S, McDearmon, of Appomattox. William T. Evans spent the week end with his parents, Mr. and Mrs. IS. J. Evans, in Petersburg He was accompanied by Mrs. Jennie John son and Miss Mary Watt Stanley. Mr. and Mrs. S. H. Wilkins, of Clifton Forge, spent the weekend .here with their daughter, Mrs. H. E. Kerr.  Friends have been advised of the illness of both Mr. and Mrs. R. Norman Dawson at the home of their niece, Mrs. Fred Roth, 164 West Taylor Rd., Philadelphia, Penn. Mr. and Mrs. Dawson left their home here just before the Christmas holidays to spend the winter with the Roths. Frank F. Carr and Clarence Moore left Monday morning for Virginia Beach where they will attend a State wide conservation meeting. While away, Mr. Moore will visit his daught er, Mrs. Joe Chinnis, at Norfolk.

document.text: E v e rg re e n . Everything is very quiet just now in and around our village, as all of the railroad men are away. Theyll soon lie back, much to the delight of some persons. There is no sickness in the village now, we are glad to state. Messrs. Edmund Cawthorn . and Hamilton have had their store root painted. Mr. Willie Gills, uear West Ap pomattox, has bought the lot form erly owned by M h . Mary Norris. He has had the stone placed for the foundation of his new house. The lot is near the church. Mr. Samuel Ferguson has had his garden nicely fenced in, which adds much to the appeaaanee of his al ready pretty home. Mrs. Albert Harveys condition is not much improved, we are sorry to say. Dr. E. E. Walker and family, of Pamplin City, were not long ago the guests of relatives near this village. Mrs. Gollie Inge and her sou, Mr. Bennie Inge, are quite ill with fever. We hope for them a quick recovery. Capt. Marshall and wife, of West Appomattox, paid a visit on Sunday afternoon to Mr. and Mrs. McDear- tnon. Mr. and Mrs. John D. Hamilton were lately the guests of her broth er, Mr. Willie Inge, near this place. Miss Mazie McDearmon will this Tuesday evening leave for Burke- ville to visit her brother, Mr. Lacy McDearmon. She will be greatly missed by all. Miss Sadie Coleman and brother, of your town, were in our village last week. We are always pleased to see her. Mr. John Rutledge, of Roanoke, was last week the guest of his par ents near this place. Miss Gracie Browning, of the old Courthouse, was last week a visitor in our village. Miss Maude Ragland returned on Sunday afteinon from KeysviLe, where she has been visiting Roanoke Bridge, the beautiful home of Miss Evie Baker. She reported that she had a pleasant visit.
